questions.question: What is a computer network?
options: Collection of interconnected computers that can communicate and share resources
questions.correct_answer: Collection of interconnected computers that can communicate and share resources
questions.explanation: A computer network is a collection of interconnected computing devices that can communicate with each other and share resources like files, printers, and internet connections.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a network topology?
questions.correct_answer: Linear
questions.explanation: Linear is not a standard network topology. The main topologies are Star, Ring, Mesh, Bus, Tree, and Hybrid.

questions.question: What does OSI stand for in networking?
questions.correct_answer: Open System Interconnection
questions.explanation: OSI stands for Open System Interconnection, which is a conceptual model that describes how network protocols should interact.

questions.question: How many layers are there in the OSI model?
questions.explanation: The OSI model has 7 layers: Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, and Application.

questions.question: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for routing?
questions.correct_answer: Network Layer
questions.explanation: The Network Layer (Layer 3) is responsible for routing packets between different networks using logical addressing (IP addresses).

questions.question: What is the full form of TCP?
questions.correct_answer: Transmission Control Protocol
questions.explanation: TCP stands for Transmission Control Protocol, which is a reliable, connection-oriented protocol used for data transmission.

questions.question: What is the full form of IP in networking?
questions.correct_answer: Internet Protocol
questions.explanation: IP stands for Internet Protocol, which is responsible for addressing and routing packets across networks.

questions.question: Which of the following is a connection-oriented protocol?
questions.correct_answer: TCP
questions.explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is connection-oriented, meaning it establishes a connection before data transfer and ensures reliable delivery.

questions.question: What does UDP stand for?
questions.correct_answer: User Datagram Protocol
questions.explanation: UDP stands for User Datagram Protocol, which is a connectionless, unreliable but fast protocol used for applications that don't require guaranteed delivery.

questions.question: Which device operates at the Physical layer of the OSI model?
questions.correct_answer: Hub
questions.explanation: A hub operates at the Physical layer (Layer 1) and simply repeats incoming signals to all connected devices without any intelligence.

questions.question: What is the default port number for HTTP?
questions.explanation: HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) uses port 80 by default for web communication.

questions.question: What is the default port number for HTTPS?
questions.explanation: HTTPS (HTTP Secure) uses port 443 by default for secure web communication using SSL/TLS encryption.

questions.question: Which protocol is used for sending emails?
questions.correct_answer: SMTP
questions.explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is used for sending emails from clients to servers and between servers.

questions.question: What does DNS stand for?
questions.correct_answer: Domain Name System
questions.explanation: DNS stands for Domain Name System, which translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses.

questions.question: Which layer of OSI model handles error detection and correction?
questions.correct_answer: Data Link Layer
questions.explanation: The Data Link Layer (Layer 2) is responsible for error detection and correction within a single network segment.

questions.question: What is a MAC address?
options: A physical address burned into network interface cards
questions.correct_answer: A physical address burned into network interface cards
questions.explanation: MAC (Media Access Control) address is a unique physical address assigned to network interface cards by manufacturers.

questions.question: Which of the following is a private IP address range?
questions.explanation: 192.168.x.x is a private IP address range used for local networks. The others are public IP addresses.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a subnet mask?
options: To determine network and host portions of an IP address
questions.correct_answer: To determine network and host portions of an IP address
questions.explanation: A subnet mask helps identify which part of an IP address represents the network and which part represents the host.

questions.question: Which device operates at the Network layer?
questions.correct_answer: Router
questions.explanation: Routers operate at the Network layer (Layer 3) and make routing decisions based on IP addresses.

questions.question: What is bandwidth in networking?
options: The maximum data transfer rate of a network connection
The number of users on a network
questions.correct_answer: The maximum data transfer rate of a network connection
questions.explanation: Bandwidth refers to the maximum amount of data that can be transmitted over a network connection in a given time period.

questions.question: What does FTP stand for?
questions.correct_answer: File Transfer Protocol
questions.explanation: FTP stands for File Transfer Protocol, which is used for transferring files between computers over a network.

questions.question: Which protocol is connectionless?
questions.correct_answer: UDP
questions.explanation: UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is connectionless, meaning it doesn't establish a connection before sending data.

questions.question: What is a switch in networking?
options: A device that connects devices within a network using MAC addresses
questions.correct_answer: A device that connects devices within a network using MAC addresses
questions.explanation: A switch is a Data Link layer device that connects devices within a network and forwards frames based on MAC addresses.

questions.question: What is the maximum length of an Ethernet cable (Cat 5e)?
questions.correct_answer: 100 meters
questions.explanation: The maximum recommended length for Ethernet cables (Cat 5e and above) is 100 meters for optimal signal quality.

questions.question: Which layer of the OSI model does HTTP operate at?
questions.correct_answer: Application Layer
questions.explanation: HTTP operates at the Application Layer (Layer 7) of the OSI model, providing web services to applications.

questions.question: What is a gateway in networking?
options: A device that connects networks with different protocols
questions.correct_answer: A device that connects networks with different protocols
questions.explanation: A gateway is a device that connects networks using different protocols and can translate between them.

questions.question: What does DHCP stand for?
questions.correct_answer: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol
questions.explanation: DHCP stands for Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol, which automatically assigns IP addresses and network configuration to devices.

questions.question: Which of the following is a network security device?
questions.correct_answer: Firewall
questions.explanation: A firewall is a network security device that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on security rules.

questions.question: What is the purpose of ARP?
options: To translate domain names to IP addresses
To translate IP addresses to MAC addresses
questions.correct_answer: To translate IP addresses to MAC addresses
questions.explanation: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) translates IP addresses to MAC addresses for local network communication.

questions.question: What is latency in networking?
options: The time delay in data transmission
The number of errors in transmission
questions.correct_answer: The time delay in data transmission
questions.explanation: Latency is the time delay between sending and receiving data over a network, often measured in milliseconds.

questions.question: What is the difference between collision domain and broadcast domain?
options: Collision domain is for physical collisions, broadcast domain is for broadcast traffic
Collision domain is larger than broadcast domain
questions.correct_answer: Collision domain is for physical collisions, broadcast domain is for broadcast traffic
questions.explanation: A collision domain is where frame collisions can occur (separated by switches), while a broadcast domain is where broadcast traffic is contained (separated by routers).

questions.question: What is VLAN and what are its benefits?
options: Virtual LAN that logically separates network traffic for better security and management
questions.correct_answer: Virtual LAN that logically separates network traffic for better security and management
questions.explanation: VLAN (Virtual LAN) logically separates network traffic on the same physical infrastructure, providing better security, performance, and network management.

questions.question: What is the difference between half-duplex and full-duplex communication?
options: Half-duplex allows communication in one direction at a time, full-duplex allows simultaneous bidirectional communication
questions.correct_answer: Half-duplex allows communication in one direction at a time, full-duplex allows simultaneous bidirectional communication
questions.explanation: Half-duplex allows communication in only one direction at a time, while full-duplex allows simultaneous communication in both directions.

questions.question: What is the purpose of sliding window protocol in TCP?
options: Flow control and efficient data transmission by allowing multiple unacknowledged segments
questions.correct_answer: Flow control and efficient data transmission by allowing multiple unacknowledged segments
questions.explanation: Sliding window protocol provides flow control and increases efficiency by allowing the sender to transmit multiple segments before waiting for acknowledgments.

questions.question: What is the difference between stop-and-wait and go-back-N ARQ?
options: Stop-and-wait sends one frame at a time, go-back-N can send multiple frames and retransmits from error point
questions.correct_answer: Stop-and-wait sends one frame at a time, go-back-N can send multiple frames and retransmits from error point
questions.explanation: Stop-and-wait ARQ sends one frame and waits for acknowledgment, while go-back-N ARQ can send multiple frames and retransmits all frames starting from the error point.

questions.question: What is the purpose of checksum in networking?
options: Error detection by calculating a value based on data content
questions.correct_answer: Error detection by calculating a value based on data content
questions.explanation: Checksum is used for error detection by calculating a value based on the data content. If the received checksum doesn't match, an error is detected.

questions.question: What is NAT and why is it used?
options: Network Address Translation used to map private IP addresses to public IP addresses
questions.correct_answer: Network Address Translation used to map private IP addresses to public IP addresses
questions.explanation: NAT (Network Address Translation) maps private IP addresses to public IP addresses, allowing multiple devices to share a single public IP address and providing security.

questions.question: What is the difference between distance vector and link state routing protocols?
options: Distance vector shares routing table with neighbors, link state shares topology information with all routers
questions.correct_answer: Distance vector shares routing table with neighbors, link state shares topology information with all routers
questions.explanation: Distance vector protocols (like RIP) share routing tables with neighbors, while link state protocols (like OSPF) share topology information with all routers to build a complete network map.

questions.question: What is the purpose of spanning tree protocol (STP)?
options: To prevent loops in switched networks by blocking redundant paths
questions.correct_answer: To prevent loops in switched networks by blocking redundant paths
questions.explanation: STP prevents loops in switched networks by identifying and blocking redundant paths while maintaining network connectivity.

questions.question: What is CSMA/CD and where is it used?
options: Collision detection mechanism used in traditional Ethernet
questions.correct_answer: Collision detection mechanism used in traditional Ethernet
questions.explanation: CSMA/CD (Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection) is used in traditional Ethernet to detect and handle collisions in shared media.

questions.question: What is the difference between circuit switching and packet switching?
options: Circuit switching establishes dedicated path, packet switching sends data in packets over shared paths
questions.correct_answer: Circuit switching establishes dedicated path, packet switching sends data in packets over shared paths
questions.explanation: Circuit switching establishes a dedicated communication path for the entire session, while packet switching breaks data into packets that travel independently over shared paths.

questions.question: What is Quality of Service (QoS) and why is it important?
options: Network management technique to prioritize traffic and ensure performance levels
questions.correct_answer: Network management technique to prioritize traffic and ensure performance levels
questions.explanation: QoS manages network resources to provide different priority levels for different types of traffic, ensuring critical applications get required bandwidth and low latency.

questions.question: What is the difference between IPv4 and IPv6?
options: IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses, IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses and provides more features
questions.correct_answer: IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses, IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses and provides more features
questions.explanation: IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses (4 billion addresses), while IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses (virtually unlimited) and includes features like built-in security and simplified header format.

questions.question: What is tunneling in networking?
options: Encapsulating one protocol inside another for transport across incompatible networks
questions.correct_answer: Encapsulating one protocol inside another for transport across incompatible networks
questions.explanation: Tunneling encapsulates packets of one protocol inside packets of another protocol, allowing transport across networks that don't natively support the original protocol.

questions.question: What is the purpose of ICMP?
options: Error reporting and diagnostic functions for IP
questions.correct_answer: Error reporting and diagnostic functions for IP
questions.explanation: ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol) provides error reporting and diagnostic functions for IP, used by tools like ping and traceroute.

questions.question: What is load balancing and why is it used?
options: Distributing network traffic across multiple servers to improve performance and reliability
questions.correct_answer: Distributing network traffic across multiple servers to improve performance and reliability
questions.explanation: Load balancing distributes incoming network traffic across multiple servers to prevent overload, improve response times, and provide redundancy.

questions.question: What is the difference between stateful and stateless protocols?
options: Stateful protocols maintain connection state, stateless protocols treat each request independently
questions.correct_answer: Stateful protocols maintain connection state, stateless protocols treat each request independently
questions.explanation: Stateful protocols (like TCP) maintain information about the connection state, while stateless protocols (like HTTP) treat each request independently.

questions.question: What is the purpose of port numbers in TCP/UDP?
options: To identify physical ports on devices
To identify specific applications or services on a device
questions.correct_answer: To identify specific applications or services on a device
questions.explanation: Port numbers identify specific applications or services running on a device, allowing the transport layer to deliver data to the correct application.

questions.question: What is the difference between unicast, multicast, and broadcast?
options: Unicast is one-to-one, multicast is one-to-many specific, broadcast is one-to-all
questions.correct_answer: Unicast is one-to-one, multicast is one-to-many specific, broadcast is one-to-all
questions.explanation: Unicast sends data to one specific recipient, multicast sends to a specific group, and broadcast sends to all devices in the network segment.

questions.question: What is the purpose of routing tables?
options: To store information about network paths and next hop for packet forwarding
questions.correct_answer: To store information about network paths and next hop for packet forwarding
questions.explanation: Routing tables store information about network destinations and the next hop (next router) to reach those destinations, enabling packet forwarding decisions.

questions.question: What is the difference between hub and switch?
options: Hub operates at physical layer and creates single collision domain, switch operates at data link layer with separate collision domains per port
questions.correct_answer: Hub operates at physical layer and creates single collision domain, switch operates at data link layer with separate collision domains per port
questions.explanation: Hubs operate at Layer 1 and create one large collision domain, while switches operate at Layer 2, creating separate collision domains for each port and learning MAC addresses.

questions.question: What is congestion control in TCP?
options: Mechanism to adjust sending rate based on network congestion to prevent packet loss
questions.correct_answer: Mechanism to adjust sending rate based on network congestion to prevent packet loss
questions.explanation: TCP congestion control adjusts the sending rate based on network conditions to prevent congestion and packet loss, using algorithms like slow start and congestion avoidance.

questions.question: What is the purpose of subnetting?
options: To divide a large network into smaller subnetworks for better management and security
questions.correct_answer: To divide a large network into smaller subnetworks for better management and security
questions.explanation: Subnetting divides a large network into smaller subnetworks, improving network performance, security, and management by reducing broadcast domains.

questions.question: What is the difference between TCP and UDP headers?
options: TCP header is larger with more fields for reliability, UDP header is smaller and simpler
questions.correct_answer: TCP header is larger with more fields for reliability, UDP header is smaller and simpler
questions.explanation: TCP header (20+ bytes) includes fields for sequence numbers, acknowledgments, and flow control, while UDP header (8 bytes) is simpler with just source/destination ports and length/checksum.

questions.question: What is the purpose of DNS caching?
options: To store DNS query results temporarily to reduce lookup time and network traffic
questions.correct_answer: To store DNS query results temporarily to reduce lookup time and network traffic
questions.explanation: DNS caching stores previously resolved domain name to IP address mappings temporarily, reducing lookup time and network traffic for subsequent requests.

questions.question: What is the difference between connection-oriented and connectionless services?
options: Connection-oriented establishes connection before data transfer, connectionless sends data without prior connection
questions.correct_answer: Connection-oriented establishes connection before data transfer, connectionless sends data without prior connection
questions.explanation: Connection-oriented services (like TCP) establish a connection before transferring data and provide reliability, while connectionless services (like UDP) send data immediately without establishing a connection.

questions.question: What is the purpose of flow control?
options: To prevent sender from overwhelming receiver by controlling data transmission rate
questions.correct_answer: To prevent sender from overwhelming receiver by controlling data transmission rate
questions.explanation: Flow control prevents the sender from transmitting data faster than the receiver can process it, preventing buffer overflow and data loss.

questions.question: What is the difference between routed and routing protocols?
options: Routed protocols carry user data (like IP), routing protocols exchange routing information (like OSPF, RIP)
questions.correct_answer: Routed protocols carry user data (like IP), routing protocols exchange routing information (like OSPF, RIP)
questions.explanation: Routed protocols (like IP, IPX) carry user data across networks, while routing protocols (like OSPF, RIP, BGP) exchange routing information between routers.

questions.question: What is the purpose of fragmentation in IP?
options: To break large packets into smaller fragments when they exceed MTU size
questions.correct_answer: To break large packets into smaller fragments when they exceed MTU size
questions.explanation: IP fragmentation breaks large packets into smaller fragments when they exceed the Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) of a network link, allowing them to traverse networks with smaller MTU sizes.

questions.question: What is the difference between persistent and non-persistent HTTP connections?
options: Persistent connections reuse TCP connection for multiple requests, non-persistent create new connection for each request
questions.correct_answer: Persistent connections reuse TCP connection for multiple requests, non-persistent create new connection for each request
questions.explanation: Persistent HTTP connections reuse the same TCP connection for multiple HTTP requests/responses, reducing overhead, while non-persistent connections create a new TCP connection for each request.

questions.question: What is BGP and why is it critical for internet routing?
options: Border Gateway Protocol that enables routing between autonomous systems on the internet
questions.correct_answer: Border Gateway Protocol that enables routing between autonomous systems on the internet
questions.explanation: BGP (Border Gateway Protocol) is the protocol that enables routing between different autonomous systems (AS) on the internet, making global internet connectivity possible by exchanging reachability information.

questions.question: What is the CAP theorem in distributed systems and how does it apply to networking?
options: States that distributed systems can only guarantee two of: Consistency, Availability, Partition tolerance
questions.correct_answer: States that distributed systems can only guarantee two of: Consistency, Availability, Partition tolerance
questions.explanation: CAP theorem states that any distributed system can only simultaneously provide two of the three guarantees: Consistency, Availability, and Partition tolerance, which affects network architecture decisions.

questions.question: What is TCP congestion window and how do slow start and congestion avoidance algorithms work?
options: Congestion window controls sending rate; slow start exponentially increases window, congestion avoidance increases linearly
questions.correct_answer: Congestion window controls sending rate; slow start exponentially increases window, congestion avoidance increases linearly
questions.explanation: TCP congestion window controls how much unacknowledged data can be in transit. Slow start exponentially increases the window size until a threshold, then congestion avoidance increases it linearly to prevent network congestion.

questions.question: What is the difference between anycast and geocast routing?
options: Anycast delivers to nearest instance of service, geocast delivers to nodes in specific geographic area
questions.correct_answer: Anycast delivers to nearest instance of service, geocast delivers to nodes in specific geographic area
questions.explanation: Anycast routing delivers packets to the nearest instance of a service (like DNS servers), while geocast routing delivers packets to all nodes within a specific geographical area.

questions.question: What is MPLS and how does it differ from traditional IP routing?
options: Multi-Protocol Label Switching that uses labels for fast forwarding instead of IP address lookups
questions.correct_answer: Multi-Protocol Label Switching that uses labels for fast forwarding instead of IP address lookups
questions.explanation: MPLS (Multi-Protocol Label Switching) uses labels attached to packets for fast forwarding decisions instead of complex IP address lookups, enabling traffic engineering and VPN services.

questions.question: What is the Byzantine Generals Problem and its relevance to network consensus?
options: Consensus problem in distributed systems with potentially malicious actors, relevant for blockchain and fault-tolerant networks
questions.correct_answer: Consensus problem in distributed systems with potentially malicious actors, relevant for blockchain and fault-tolerant networks
questions.explanation: The Byzantine Generals Problem addresses achieving consensus in distributed systems where some nodes may be malicious or unreliable, critical for blockchain networks and fault-tolerant distributed systems.

questions.question: What is TCP Fast Recovery and how does it improve performance?
options: Algorithm that avoids slow start after packet loss by maintaining congestion window size
questions.correct_answer: Algorithm that avoids slow start after packet loss by maintaining congestion window size
questions.explanation: TCP Fast Recovery algorithm allows TCP to recover from packet loss without entering slow start, maintaining higher throughput by keeping the congestion window size larger during recovery.

questions.question: What is the difference between reactive and proactive routing protocols in mobile ad-hoc networks?
options: Reactive protocols find routes on-demand, proactive protocols maintain routes continuously
questions.correct_answer: Reactive protocols find routes on-demand, proactive protocols maintain routes continuously
questions.explanation: Reactive routing protocols (like AODV) discover routes only when needed, while proactive protocols (like OLSR) continuously maintain routing information, each with trade-offs in overhead and delay.

questions.question: What is network function virtualization (NFV) and its benefits?
options: Running network functions as software on standard hardware instead of dedicated appliances
questions.correct_answer: Running network functions as software on standard hardware instead of dedicated appliances
questions.explanation: NFV virtualizes network functions (like firewalls, load balancers) as software running on commodity hardware, reducing costs, increasing flexibility, and enabling rapid service deployment.

questions.question: What is Software-Defined Networking (SDN) and how does it change traditional networking?
options: Architecture that separates control plane from data plane, enabling centralized network control
questions.correct_answer: Architecture that separates control plane from data plane, enabling centralized network control
questions.explanation: SDN separates the network control plane from the data plane, allowing centralized control and programmability of network behavior through software controllers like OpenFlow.

questions.question: What is the difference between cut-through and store-and-forward switching?
options: Cut-through starts forwarding before receiving complete frame, store-and-forward waits for complete frame
questions.correct_answer: Cut-through starts forwarding before receiving complete frame, store-and-forward waits for complete frame
questions.explanation: Cut-through switching begins forwarding a frame as soon as the destination address is read, while store-and-forward switching receives the entire frame before forwarding, providing error checking but higher latency.

questions.question: What is TCP selective acknowledgment (SACK) and how does it improve performance?
options: Extension allowing receiver to acknowledge non-contiguous blocks of data to improve loss recovery
questions.correct_answer: Extension allowing receiver to acknowledge non-contiguous blocks of data to improve loss recovery
questions.explanation: TCP SACK allows the receiver to acknowledge non-contiguous blocks of correctly received data, enabling the sender to retransmit only the missing segments instead of all segments after the first loss.

questions.question: What is the purpose of RSVP in networking and how does it work?
options: Resource Reservation Protocol for reserving network resources along a path for QoS
questions.correct_answer: Resource Reservation Protocol for reserving network resources along a path for QoS
questions.explanation: RSVP (Resource Reservation Protocol) allows applications to reserve network resources (bandwidth, buffer space) along a path to ensure Quality of Service for real-time applications.

questions.question: What is traffic shaping and how does it differ from traffic policing?
options: Traffic shaping buffers excess traffic to smooth flow, traffic policing drops or marks excess traffic
questions.correct_answer: Traffic shaping buffers excess traffic to smooth flow, traffic policing drops or marks excess traffic
questions.explanation: Traffic shaping buffers excess packets to smooth out bursty traffic and maintain a steady rate, while traffic policing immediately drops or marks packets that exceed the configured rate.

questions.question: What is the count-to-infinity problem in distance vector routing and how is it solved?
options: Problem where incorrect routing information propagates slowly, solved by techniques like split horizon
questions.correct_answer: Problem where incorrect routing information propagates slowly, solved by techniques like split horizon
questions.explanation: Count-to-infinity occurs when incorrect routing information propagates slowly through the network in distance vector protocols, solved by techniques like split horizon, poison reverse, and hold-down timers.

questions.question: What is IPv6 header compression and why is it important for IoT?
options: 6LoWPAN compression reduces IPv6 header overhead for constrained IoT devices
questions.correct_answer: 6LoWPAN compression reduces IPv6 header overhead for constrained IoT devices
questions.explanation: IPv6 header compression, particularly in 6LoWPAN (IPv6 over Low-Power Wireless Personal Area Networks), reduces the large IPv6 header overhead to make it suitable for resource-constrained IoT devices.

questions.question: What is the difference between hard and soft QoS guarantees?
options: Hard QoS provides absolute guarantees with admission control, soft QoS provides statistical guarantees
questions.correct_answer: Hard QoS provides absolute guarantees with admission control, soft QoS provides statistical guarantees
questions.explanation: Hard QoS provides absolute guarantees for delay, bandwidth, and loss with strict admission control, while soft QoS provides statistical guarantees and best-effort service differentiation.

questions.question: What is TCP timestamp option and how does it help with performance?
options: Enables better RTT measurement and protection against wrapped sequence numbers
questions.correct_answer: Enables better RTT measurement and protection against wrapped sequence numbers
questions.explanation: TCP timestamp option provides accurate round-trip time measurements for better congestion control and protects against wrapped sequence numbers in high-bandwidth networks (PAWS - Protection Against Wrapped Sequences).

questions.question: What is the purpose of ECMP (Equal-Cost Multi-Path) routing?
options: Load balancing traffic across multiple equal-cost paths to improve utilization and reliability
questions.correct_answer: Load balancing traffic across multiple equal-cost paths to improve utilization and reliability
questions.explanation: ECMP allows routers to load balance traffic across multiple paths with equal cost to the same destination, improving network utilization and providing redundancy.

questions.question: What is network coding and how can it improve throughput?
options: Technique where intermediate nodes combine packets algebraically to reduce transmissions
questions.correct_answer: Technique where intermediate nodes combine packets algebraically to reduce transmissions
questions.explanation: Network coding allows intermediate nodes to combine multiple packets algebraically and forward the coded packet, reducing the total number of transmissions needed and improving network throughput.

questions.question: What is the purpose of QUIC protocol and how does it improve web performance?
options: Transport protocol built on UDP that reduces connection establishment overhead and provides multiplexing
questions.correct_answer: Transport protocol built on UDP that reduces connection establishment overhead and provides multiplexing
questions.explanation: QUIC (Quick UDP Internet Connections) is a transport protocol that reduces connection establishment latency, provides built-in encryption, and enables multiplexing without head-of-line blocking.

questions.question: What is the difference between centralized and distributed network management?
options: Centralized uses single control point, distributed shares management across multiple nodes with different trade-offs
questions.correct_answer: Centralized uses single control point, distributed shares management across multiple nodes with different trade-offs
questions.explanation: Centralized management provides global optimization and consistency but creates single points of failure, while distributed management offers resilience and scalability but faces coordination challenges.

questions.question: What is the purpose of segment routing and how does it differ from traditional MPLS?
options: Source-based routing that encodes path in packet header, simplifying network state management
questions.correct_answer: Source-based routing that encodes path in packet header, simplifying network state management
questions.explanation: Segment routing encodes the forwarding path as a list of segments in the packet header, eliminating per-flow state in intermediate nodes and simplifying traffic engineering compared to traditional MPLS.

questions.question: What is intent-based networking (IBN) and how does it change network management?
options: Network management approach that translates business intent into network configuration automatically
questions.correct_answer: Network management approach that translates business intent into network configuration automatically
questions.explanation: Intent-based networking allows administrators to specify high-level business policies and intent, which the system automatically translates into detailed network configurations and continuously monitors for compliance.

questions.question: What is the challenge of head-of-line blocking in HTTP/2 and how does HTTP/3 solve it?
options: TCP head-of-line blocking affects all streams; HTTP/3 uses QUIC with independent streams
questions.correct_answer: TCP head-of-line blocking affects all streams; HTTP/3 uses QUIC with independent streams
questions.explanation: HTTP/2 multiplexes streams over single TCP connection, but TCP head-of-line blocking affects all streams. HTTP/3 uses QUIC to provide truly independent streams without head-of-line blocking.

questions.question: What is the difference between edge and fog computing in terms of network architecture?
options: Edge computing processes at network edge, fog computing creates hierarchical processing layers
questions.correct_answer: Edge computing processes at network edge, fog computing creates hierarchical processing layers
questions.explanation: Edge computing moves processing to the network edge closest to devices, while fog computing creates a hierarchical architecture with multiple processing layers between devices and cloud.

questions.question: What is network slicing in 5G and why is it important?
options: Creating multiple virtual networks with different characteristics on shared infrastructure
questions.correct_answer: Creating multiple virtual networks with different characteristics on shared infrastructure
questions.explanation: 5G network slicing creates multiple virtual networks with different performance characteristics (latency, bandwidth, reliability) on the same physical infrastructure to serve diverse use cases.

questions.question: What is the Byzantine fault tolerance and its application in blockchain networks?
options: Consensus mechanism that tolerates up to 1/3 malicious nodes in distributed systems
questions.correct_answer: Consensus mechanism that tolerates up to 1/3 malicious nodes in distributed systems
questions.explanation: Byzantine Fault Tolerance enables distributed systems to reach consensus even when up to 1/3 of nodes are malicious or failed, critical for blockchain networks and fault-tolerant distributed systems.

questions.question: What is the difference between in-band and out-of-band network management?
options: In-band uses same network for data and management, out-of-band uses separate management network
questions.correct_answer: In-band uses same network for data and management, out-of-band uses separate management network
questions.explanation: In-band management uses the same network infrastructure for both data and management traffic, while out-of-band management uses a separate, dedicated network for management functions, providing better security and availability.

questions.question: What is P4 (Programming Protocol-independent Packet Processors) and its significance?
options: Domain-specific language for programming network data plane behavior in switches and routers
questions.correct_answer: Domain-specific language for programming network data plane behavior in switches and routers
questions.explanation: P4 is a domain-specific programming language that allows developers to define how network switches and routers process packets, enabling protocol-independent and programmable data plane functionality.
